references:
We develop an energy-efficient framework to facilitate the introduced FL-EOCD scheme for the energy-limited devices in the partially connected D2D network. We formulate an optimization problem to minimize both the computation and communication energy consumption of the devices subject to constraints on FL time, device connectivity, scheduling among the device-CH/RRB, and computation frequency allocation. The proposed joint optimization problem is NP-hard, and thus the global optimal solution
is computationally intractable. To tackle such difficult optimization
problem, an iterative solution framework is devised. Specifically, the overall CH selection, device-CH scheduling, and computation frequency allocation problem is
decomposed into two sub-problems, namely, CHs selection and their devices scheduling sub-problem and computation frequency allocation sub-problem. For each sub-problem, we propose a solution of polynomial computational
complexity, and rigorously justify the effectiveness
of the proposed solutions. By iteratively solving these sub-problems, an FL-EOCD algorithm is developed to minimize the energy consumption.

In P0, C1 indicates that each local device is assigned to only one CH and to only one RRB in that CH; C2 indicates that at maximum one BD can be assigned to two adjacent CHs at the same time. In practice and due to the nature of D2D communications, we can have more than one BD at the overlap regions of adjacent CHs. In this case, the BD in the middle of overlapped regions is selected and other BDs are scheduled to the most suitable CHs. C3 is the constraint on local computation resource allocation of devices; and C4 indicates the QoS requirement on the FL time.

A suitable solution to P1 is obtained by iteratively solving the
sub-problems P2 and P3. The sub-problems P2 and P3 are solved in Section IV-C and Section IV-D, respectively, and the overall algorithm to solve P1 is provided in Section V-A.

P2 considers a joint optimization of both
CHs selection and their scheduled devices and BDs, denoted
by 𝒞∈𝒫​(𝒩)𝒞𝒫𝒩\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N}), 𝒩lsubscript𝒩𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l}, and ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, respectively. In particular, P2 involves inner and outer optimization problems: the inner one optimizes the device/BD scheduling to reduce
the network utility function while the outer one aims at finding the most suitable CHs. Therefore, the joint inner and outer optimization sub-problem P2, for a given fn∗​∀n∈𝒩lsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛for-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙f^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}, can be given at the top of the next page.

Unfortunately, the outer optimization problem (21) and the inner optimization problem (22) of P2.1 are inter-dependent and should be solved jointly. Solving P2.1 optimally using an exhaustive search is intractable [42, 43]. In this work, we develop a tractable graph theoretical and clustering method that carefully selects the number of clusters, their corresponding CHs, and scheduled local devices/BDs. As such, it achieves an effective solution to the optimization problem P2.1.
The overall steps followed by the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm to obtain a suitable solution to problem P0 are summarized in Algorithm 2. FL-EOCD has two stages, namely, Stage-I and Stage-II.

(1) Stage-I: The required steps to implement Stage-I are provided as follows. At the beginning, the BS obtains the
locations of the devices. Thereafter, based on the
current computation frequency allocation, the BS designs the FL local graph of each device and judiciously finds the suitable CH clustering and the local device scheduling. Specifically, in order to determine the CHs and schedule the devices, the BS constructs the clustering and the corresponding graph, and then performs the greedy vertex-weighting algorithm [44, 45]. First, the BS selects the vertex that has the following features: (i) it has a minimum weight in terms of energy consumption and (ii) it is connected to many neighbors that have minimum weights. Next, it constructs the set of vertices that are connected to the selected vertex, and then finds the second minimum-weight vertex. This process is repeated until no neighbors are available in the designed clustering, and this is summarized in lines 21-25 of Algorithm 1. Meanwhile, the BS calculates the FL time of the scheduled devices according to (17) to check the feasibility of the scheduled local devices. Next, for each scheduled device, the BS updates the variable fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}. The aforementioned steps are iteratively repeated until the computation frequency allocation constraints over all the scheduled local devices are satisfied or the maximum number of iterations is reached. Upon convergence in Stage-I (i.e., lines 3-7 of Algorithm 2), the set of CH clustering, device/BD scheduling, and computation frequency allocation among the scheduled local devices are obtained.

(1) Network configuration: For the numerical performance evaluations, we consider a circular network area having a radius of 900900900 m with one BS at its center and multiple randomly distributed devices. The channel model for D2D transmissions follows the standard model [22], which consists of three components: 1) path-loss of 148+40​log10⁡(dis.[km])14840subscript10dis.[km]148+40\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}); 2) log-normal shadowing with 444 dB standard deviation; and 3) Rayleigh channel fading with zero-mean and unit variance. On the other hand, the path-loss of the cellular is 128.1+37.6​log10⁡(dis.[km])128.137.6subscript10dis.[km]128.1+37.6\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}) [35, 36]. We consider that the channels are perfectly estimated. The noise power and maximum local device (BD and CH) power are assumed to be −174174-174 dBm/Hz and pn=pc=1subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑐1p_{n}=p_{c}=1 W, respectively. The transmit power of the BS is set to 333 W. The bandwidth of each RRB is 222 MHz. Unless otherwise stated, we set the numbers of devices to 262626 and we consider 222222 RRBs in the system. The
remaining simulation parameters that are selected based on [12, 13] are summarized in Table I. In the ensuing simulation
results, each simulation experiment is repeated 200200200 times with randomly generated devices’ locations, and the average
results over all the considered simulation instances are presented. We consider a deep learning image classification problem over MNIST dataset [27]. The considered dataset contains 606060 K images, where each image is one of 101010 labels. We divide the
dataset into the devices’ local data 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} with non-i.i.d. data heterogeneity, where each local dataset contains datapoints from two of the 101010 labels. In each case, 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} is selected randomly from the full dataset of labels assigned to n𝑛n-th device. We also assume non-iid-clustering, where the maximum number of assigned classes for each cluster is 666 classes. For ML models, we use a deep neural network with 333 convolutional layers and 111 fully connected layer. The total number of trainable parameters is 909890989098.
